December 2020 
 
 
 
 
Republic of Azerbaijan: Fostering Development of 
Local Tech Startups

Policy.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  support  INNOLAND,  an 
incubation, acceleration, and research center of the Innovations Center LLC at the State Agency 
for Public Services and Social Innovations (SAPSSI) under the President of Azerbaijan, to set up 
effective and efficient local institutional arrangements to support tech startups.1 
 
2.  The TA is aligned with the strategic pillars of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) country 
partnership strategy (CPS) for Azerbaijan, 2019–2023 on boosting private sector development 
and strengthening human capital.2 It is also in line with the crosscutting priority of ADB’s CPS to 
strengthen governance through information and communication technology (ICT). The TA is 
included in ADB’s country operations business plan for Azerbaijan, 2020–2022.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The Government of Azerbaijan recognizes the importance of digital development for 
making the national economy knowledge-based, and considers the development of the ICT sector 
to be an important element of the diversification of the economy away from hydrocarbons.4 The 
government views tech startups as a driving force for the country’s ICT sector and digital 
transformation, and as a source of innovative solutions and productivity growth for the economy.5 
ADB’s CPS envisages support for expanding ICT infrastructure and services in the regions. This 
includes  fostering  digital  microbusinesses  and  small  and  medium-sized  enterprises  and 
strengthening the enabling environment for the digital economy. 
 
4.  Tech startup growth is constrained by regulatory gaps, lack of knowledge on how to 
access finance, a lack of digital literacy, and limited awareness of the opportunities available for 
tech startups. Promoting the emergence of tech startups in the regions outside the Absheron 
Peninsula, which is the location of the capital, Baku, and the center of the country’s economic 
activity, is particularly challenging. Baku generated 71.8% of national output and received 74.5% 
of total capital investment in 2016.6 The regions’ economic and digital lag, compounded by a 
shortage of ICT infrastructure,7especially affects the youth, women, and people with disabilities 
who suffer most from unemployment and lack of economic opportunities.8 The Azerbaijan Digital 
 
1  More  details  on  INNOLAND  can  be  accessed  at  http://innoland.az/en  and  the  Innovation  Center  at 
https://www.icenter.az/en. 
2  ADB. 2019. Country Partnership Strategy: Azerbaijan, 2019–2023—Promoting Diversified and Inclusive Growth. 
Manila. 
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 1 April 2020. ADB. 2019. Country 
Operations Business Plan: Azerbaijan, 2020–2022. Manila. The TA has been included in ADB’s country operations 
business plan under the title Digital Technologies for Economic Diversification programmed for 2020. 
4  Strategic Roadmap for Development of Telecommunications and Information Technologies in Azerbaijan (adopted 
by the Presidential Decree no. 1138 dated 6 December 2016); and the State Program on Socio-Economic 
Development of the Regions of the Republic of Azerbaijan for 2019–2023 (adopted the Presidential Decree no. 500 
dated 29 January 2019). 
5  Tech startups are entrepreneurial ventures that deliver new, innovative, and scalable technology-based products and 
services to the market. Where such products and services already exist, tech startups introduce new ways to deliver 
them. The hallmark of startups is their creativity, which establishes new business models for the economy, and thus 
distinguishes tech startups from other small and medium-sized enterprises. 
6 ADB. 2019. Country Partnership Strategy: Azerbaijan, 2019–2023—Promoting Diversified and Inclusive Growth. 
Manila. 
7  ADB. 2019. Azerbaijan: Country Digital Development Overview. Baku. 
8 In Azerbaijan, only 16% of women use internet services on their phones, and only 27% of women entrepreneurs use 
computers for entrepreneurial activities. This pattern is more marked for women in rural areas. ADB. 2014. Information 
and Communication Technologies for Women Entrepreneurs: Prospects and Potential in Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, 
the Kyrgyz Republic, and Uzbekistan. Manila.

2 
Hub program is a public–private effort aimed at improving the country’s ICT connectivity by 
building fiber-optic cables in the country and constructing the Trans-Caspian fiber-optic cable with 
the ultimate objective of transforming the country into a regional digital hub.9 The quarantine 
regime,  distant  work  arrangements,  and  need  for  quick  and  efficient  outreach  to  various 
population groups during the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic have crystalized the 
importance and urgency of improving the ICT infrastructure and governance and spurring the 
digitalization of the economy.10 
 
5.  The government has been taking measures to strengthen the enabling environment for 
the emergence and growth of a robust startups industry beyond the Absheron Peninsula. It also 
fosters the development of startups through several agencies. In 2019 there were more than 20 
public and private startup incubation and acceleration centers in Azerbaijan. Tech startups that 
fall into the small and medium-sized enterprises category and have received startup certificates 
are exempt from profit tax on innovative activities for 3 years. 
 
6.  The Innovation Center under SAPSSI is one of the leading agencies for facilitating the 
development of tech startups in Azerbaijan and promoting links with tech startups abroad. In the 
Silicon Valley, the United States (US), INNOLAND established the Azerbaijan “Tech Diaspora,” a 
forum that brings together Azerbaijanis who work for leading digital companies such as Facebook, 
Google, and Twitter. As part of this process, Azerbaijan’s Innovations House, which will support 
startups in the country, was inaugurated at Stanford University in the US in February 2020. To 
promote  the  development  of  tech  startups  in  Azerbaijan’s  regions  from  2020,  INNOLAND 
announced the opening of incubation centers in Ganja and Sheki, the target regions of the TA. 
 
7.  In Ganja, INNOLAND intends to deliver incubation and acceleration assistance (IAA) 
through the Department of Innovations of Ganja State University (GSU); and Azerbaijan State 
Agrarian University (ASAU), which will focus on tech startups related to agriculture. In Sheki, the 
IAA is planned to be delivered through INNOLAND’s branch office ─ INNOLAND Sheki. ASAU, 
GSU,  and  INNOLAND  Sheki  require  comprehensive  capacity  building  to  enable  them  to 
sustainably deliver IAA and eventually become regional tech startup facilitation hubs. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: startups to support innovative solutions in 
rural and nonrural production areas created, developed, and promoted.11 The TA will have the 
following outcome: local capacity for effective facilitation of tech startups strengthened. The 
intended outcome will be achieved through implementation of the outputs described in paras. 9–
11.12 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output 1: Enabling environment for local tech startups strengthened. This output will 
include (i) undertaking a diagnostic study of the generic and sector-specific enabling environment 
 
9  Details on the Azerbaijan Digital Hub initiative can be accessed here https://www.azertelecom.az/en/projects/key/. 
10 About 65% of internet market falls under government-owned operators. Telecommunication infrastructure is also 
mostly in public hands. This may limit the competition and hence reduce the potential price and quality efficiencies. 
11 Presidential Decree on State Program on Socio-Economic Development of the Regions of the Republic of Azerbaijan 
in 2019–2023 (no. 500 dated 29 January 2019). 
12 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
for tech startups in the two target regions;13 (ii) developing a strategy for establishing efficient and 
sustainable institutional arrangements for startup facilitation;14 and (iii) preparing an action plan 
to support the growth of tech startups at the target institutions (ASAU, GSU, and INNOLAND 
Sheki). 
 
10.  Output 2: Local institutional setup for tech startup development improved. This 
output will help INNOLAND and the target institutions plan and execute the IAA based on the 
diagnostic study, medium- and long-term strategies, and the action plan developed under output 
1. Output 2 will involve the design and roll-out of capacity-building programs that will be designed 
based on consultations with local stakeholders, including women, in the target regions. These 
programs will help local tech startups develop fundamental skills, such as business accounting, 
taxation,  and marketing;  and  advanced  skills, such  as  creativity,  persuasion,  collaboration, 
adaptability, and elevator pitch presentation. The output will also support the preparation and 
delivery of such knowledge activities as workshops and startup competitions (e.g., idea fests and 
hackathons) to be held in cooperation with public and private sector startup event organizers. 
INNOLAND  will  engage  Azerbaijan  Tech  Diaspora  and  Azerbaijan’s  Innovations  House  to 
organize the knowledge activities, which will also be coordinated with the Azerbaijan Digital Hub 
program and the ADB Ventures platform.15 
 
11.  Output 3: Knowledge partnerships developed. This output will support the creation of 
twinning partnerships between Azerbaijan’s tech startup facilitators (INNOLAND and the target 
institutions) and their counterpart centers of excellence in Asia and the Pacific.16 This may entail 
supporting internships for selected staff of INNOLAND, INNOLAND Sheki, ASAU, and GSU with 
the twinning partners; short-term visits of the twinning partner staff for specific knowledge transfer 
or on-the-job training; and topic-specific study tours, including for tech startups.17 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $550,000, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund (EAKPF) and administered by 
ADB. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
13.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of office accommodation, 
venues for activities, communication facilities for consultants, remuneration for TA focal persons 
assigned, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
 
13 Generic factors pertain to the regulatory framework, institutional setup, existing startup incubation programs, human 
resources, ICT infrastructure, financing, and real sector dynamics. The review will consider the ecosystem factors 
pertinent to startups in fintech, e-commerce, cleantech, agritech, education technology, and healthtech; and analyze 
the optimal design options for tech startup incubators. The review will also discuss relevant international experience 
in creating a conducive environment for startups, including practices from Germany, the Republic of Korea, 
Singapore, and the US. 
14 This output will build on ADB’s research on constraints to the growth of startups in Azerbaijan (completed in 
December 2019); and will focus on the development of startups in clean energy, agriculture, health, and education, 
with special attention paid to startups with strong gender and climate impacts. 
15 ADB Ventures is a platform established in January 2020 to support and invest in startups offering impact technology 
solutions that contribute to the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals in Asia and the Pacific. 
16 The twinning partners will be defined during the implementation of output 1 in consultation with and facilitated by the 
Digital Technology for Development Unit of ADB’s Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department. The 
possibility of building a twinning partnership with Silicon Valley will also be considered. 
17 This output may also support staff of other government agencies involved in tech startup facilitation, subject to 
SAPSSI’s request, the availability of TA budget, and the agreement of ADB.

4 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB,  through  the  Azerbaijan  Resident  Mission  of  ADB’s  Central  and  West  Asia 
Department,  will  administer  the  TA.  The  resident  mission  will  coordinate  with  the  Digital 
Technology  for  Development  Unit  of  the  Sustainable  Development  and  Climate  Change 
Department and the Central and West Asia Department’s Transport and Communications Division 
during TA implementation.  
 
15.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
16.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.18 
 
17.  Several government agencies support the development of the tech startup industry at the 
national and sector levels.19 To ensure efforts are synchronized and duplication avoided, the 
Innovation Center under SAPSSI will establish and operationalize a TA coordination group 
comprising representatives of the government agencies concerned. The TA coordination group 
will review semiannual TA progress reports prepared by the project coordinator, and will convene 
each time ADB’s TA review mission is fielded, which is expected to be at least twice a year. The 
Innovation Center under SAPSSI will facilitate representation of government agencies at the level 
 
18 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3). 
19 Government agencies involved in startup or digital economy facilitation include the Innovation Agency under the 
Ministry  of  Transport,  Communication  and  High  Technologies;  the  Small  and  Medium-Sized  Enterprises 
Development Agency under the Ministry of Economy; the Youth Foundation; the Agrarian Science and Innovation 
Center under the Ministry of Agriculture; the Center for Analysis of Economic Reforms and Communication; the State 
Employment Service under the Ministry of Labor and Social Protection of Population, and Azercosmos Open Joint 
Stock Company.

5 
of head of department or higher. Selected outcomes of the TA will be shared with internal and 
external clients in form of suitable knowledge products and services to be developed by the 
Azerbaijan Resident Mission with support of TA consultants.20 
 
18.  The EAKPF requires an annual progress report to be submitted within the first month after 
the end of each calendar year. ADB’s resident mission will prepare and submit such progress 
reports to the EAKPF manager at ADB. The resident mission will also coordinate with the office 
of the Korea International Cooperation Agency in Azerbaijan during implementation of the TA. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development Bank administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 
to the Government of Azerbaijan to be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia 
and Knowledge Partnership Fund for Fostering Development of Local Tech Startups, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board. 
 
 
20 The TA will tap the support from the TA on Strengthening Delivery of Knowledge Products and Services in Azerbaijan 
being developed by ADB’s Azerbaijan Resident Mission for delivery in 2020.

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Enabling environment for regional tech startups strengthened 
1.1  Conduct a generic and sector-specific diagnostic review for startup ecosystem development in terms of 
regulatory environment, institutional capacity, human resources, and financial market in two target regions (Q1 
2021). 
1.2  Conduct at least one roundtable discussion among government institutions that support digital technology 
startups in Azerbaijan (Q1 2021). 
1.3  Develop medium- to long-term strategies with recommendations on interventions in the two target regions, and 
prepare an action plan for ASAU, GSU, and INNOLAND Sheki (Q2 2021). 
2.  Local institutional setup for tech startup development improved 
2.1  Develop capacity-building program on startup facilitation, incubation, and acceleration service delivery by ASAU, 
GSU, and INNOLAND Sheki (Q2 2021), 
2.2.  Deliver capacity-building program to government stakeholders, with focus on ASAU, GSU, INNOLAND Baku, 
and INNOLAND Sheki Q3 2021). 
2.3  Conduct competition events with a focus on the regional development agenda, in cooperation with domestic 
public and private sector organizations (Q3 2021). 
3.  Knowledge partnerships developed 
3.1  Establish cooperation agreements with organizations supporting startups in partner countries with excellence in 
tech startups, and conduct study tours and staff exchanges between the selected countries and Azerbaijan (Q3 
2021). 
3.2  Support participation of tech startups at international competitions of selected tech startups from Ganja and 
Sheki regions (Q4 2021). 
 
TA Management Activities 
 
Recruit project coordinator (national individual consultant) (Q1 2021). 
Recruit consulting firm (Q1 2021). 
Prepare final TA progress report (Q2 2022). 
Disseminate reports and lessons learned through selected knowledge products and services (Q2 2022). 
Inputs

support in the form of office accommodation, venues for activities, communication facilities for consultants, 
remuneration for TA focal persons assigned, and other in-kind contributions.

None

Source: Asian Development Bank.
